awd_titl_txt: A Practice-Based Online Learning Environment for Scientific Inquiry with Digitized Museum Collections in Middle School Classrooms
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

There are an estimated 2-4 billion specimens in the world's natural history collections that contain the data necessary to address complex global issues, including biodiversity and climate. Digitized natural history collections present an untapped opportunity to engage learners in crucial questions of science with far-reaching potential consequences via object-based research investigations.  This project will develop and study a prototype online learning environment that supports student learning via Engaging Practices for Inquiry with Collections in Bioscience (EPIC Bioscience). EPIC Bioscience uses authentic research investigations with digitized collections from natural history museums.  The project team will create a curriculum aligned with the Next Generation of Science Standards (NGSS) for middle school students, emphasizing a major disciplinary core idea in grades 6-8 life science, Ecosystems: Interactions, Energy, and Dynamics. The project has three major goals: 1) Develop an online learning environment that guides students through research investigations using digitized natural history collections to teach NGSS life science standards. 2) Investigate how interactive features and conversational scaffolds in the EPIC Bioscience learning environment can promote deeper processing of science content and effective knowledge building. 3) Demonstrate effective approaches to using digitized collections objects for contextualized, research-based science learning that aligns to NGSS standards for middle school classrooms.

The project will examine how and when interactive features of a digital learning environment can be combined with deep questions and effective online scaffolds to promote student engagement, meaningful collaborative discourse, and robust learning outcomes during research with digitized museum collections. Research activities will address: How can interactive features of EPIC Bioscience help students learn disciplinary core ideas and cross cutting concepts via science practices through collections-based research? How can effective patterns of collaborative scientific discourse be supported and enhanced during online, collections-based research? How does the use of digitized scientific collections influence students' levels of engagement and depth of processing during classroom investigations? A significant impact of the proposed work is expanded opportunities for research with authentic museum objects for populations who are traditionally underserved in STEM and are underrepresented in museum visitor demographics (Title I schools, racial/ethnic minorities, and rural school populations). Research activities will engage over 1,500 Title I and rural students (50 classes across three years) in meaningful research investigations with collections objects that address pressing global issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Objectives

The project's objectives were to:

  • Develop an online learning environment (EPIC Bioscience) for middle school science that guides students through authentic research investigations focused on digitized specimens from natural history collections and aligned to Next Generation Science Standards for middle school life science (NGSS MS-LS2-1 through NGSS MS-LS2-4).
  • Demonstrate effective approaches to using digitized collections objects for engaging students in authentic science practices via online investigations.
  • Investigate the impact of EPIC Bioscience investigations on student learning outcomes and explore students' and teachers' perceptions of investigation quality and value.

Major Outcomes

Four online science investigations centered on digitized specimens from varied museum collections were developed and published on ResearchQuest.org (https://researchquest.org/epic/). Investigations are available at no cost for educational use by anyone with a free Research Quest account.

  • NGSS MS-LS2-1: Insect Apocalypse! (Vertebrate Zoology): https://researchquest.org/epic/bats/  Students investigate digitized bat specimens to examine how the physical features of an organism may impact its dietary adaptability during times of resource scarcity. Students develop an evidence-based argument about varied risk to species posed by resource scarcity.
  • NGSS MS-LS2-2: To Eat or Not to Eat (Entomology): https://researchquest.org/epic/velvetants/  Students investigate the physical features of potential prey that influence predator behavior. Students gather data from a harmful species (velvet ants) and harmless mimics (jumping spiders) to determine which features cause predators to avoid them. Students develop an evidence-based argument about how ecosystem changes may affect predator-prey relationships when populations of harmful species or mimics vary.
  • NGSS MS-LS2-3: Decomposition -- It's a Dirt-y Job (Mycology): https://researchquest.org/epic/fungi/  Students investigate the abundance and richness of fungal micro-remains in xeric (dry) and mesic (moist) soil samples from wild or urban environments. Students reason about how the abundance and richness of fungi help explain the speed of matter cycling in ecosystems. Students develop an evidence-based argument about how humans may impact fungi populations in soils and connect their thinking to local communities.
  • NGSS MS-LS2-4: Aspen Restoration (Botany):  https://researchquest.org/epic/aspens/  Students investigate the health of aspen forests, using a streamlined version of forest managers' data collection and decision making. Students determine if a restoration plan is needed and use their data to select an optimal treatment approach. Students develop an evidence-based argument about the benefits and challenges of their restoration plan.

Using a series of pilot tests and classroom studies, the project developed a structured approach for online investigations that supports student engagement in digitized research across flexible learning contexts (i.e., asynchronous, self-paced learning in addition to synchronous, classroom learning). This structure has three basic components:

  1. Learn-by-doing introduction. The learn-by-doing introduction allows expedited engagement with science content and helps motivate data collection by sparking students' questions. Each introduction has minimal instruction, allowing students to dive into the content without extensive preparation. Activities vary in format (educational games, virtual simulation) and engage students in wondering how, why, or when scientific phenomena occur.
  2. Guided data collection and analysis from museum specimens. This is the core of each investigation, where students engage in realistic research with digitized museum collections. Students gather data directly from museum specimens (via measuring, rating, counting, sorting, etc.) and are guided through analysis and interpretation. By the end of the investigation, students make an evidence-based argument related to a scientific question.
  3. Concluding application and communication. To end each investigation, students apply their findings to new situations, future contexts, or real-world settings. Students may reason about scenarios, develop evidence-based strategies or plans, or infer future impact.

Classroom studies found significant, positive impacts of EPIC investigation use on students' learning outcomes compared to "business as usual" classroom activities. Students and teachers rated the investigations positively, reporting strong engagement and high pedagogical value. Teachers report that investigations are useful tools to help students experience authentic science practices and to improve student data literacy.

Intellectual Merit

This project demonstrates the strong role that digitized museum objects can play in supporting realistic, online science research for middle school students, using a learning environment that is widely available and practical for classroom implementation. Classroom testing demonstrated significant impact of EPIC Bioscience investigations on student learning and strong student engagement with specimens from museum collections; it also demonstrated that teachers can implement investigations with few modifications. Results from project testing showed that online research investigations are well-supported by self-paced content, multimedia instruction, compelling museum specimens, and ample interactive scaffolds.

Broader Impacts

This project has created new opportunities for middle school students to engage in realistic research with digitized specimens, allowing earlier opportunities to gain experience in science practices and to develop data literacy skills. EPIC investigations are published online and are free for educational use. To date, 340 teachers have utilized one or more of the investigations online. A conservative estimate of 20 students per teacher means that EPIC Bioscience investigations have reached over 6,000 students during the project, resulting in more than 98,000 page views across investigations.
